sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations with multiple solutions
message_2:
To solve the system of linear equations using matrix methods, we first write the given system in matrix form:

$$
\begin{bmatrix}
3 & -4 \\
6 & -8
\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}
x \\
y
\end{bmatrix}
=
\begin{bmatrix}
8 \\
16
\end{bmatrix}
$$

Now, we can use the Gaussian elimination method to solve the system. First, we form the augmented matrix:

$$
\left[
\begin{array}{cc|c}
3 & -4 & 8 \\
6 & -8 & 16
\end{array}
\right]
$$

We can simplify the second row by dividing it by 2:

$$
\left[
\begin{array}{cc|c}
3 & -4 & 8 \\
3 & -4 & 8
\end{array}
\right]
$$

Now, we subtract the first row from the second row to eliminate the x term in the second row:

$$
\left[
\begin{array}{cc|c}
3 & -4 & 8 \\
0 & 0 & 0
\end{array}
\right]
$$

At this point, we can see that the second equation is 0 = 0, which means the two equations are dependent and represent the same line. Therefore, there are infinitely many solutions to this system of equations, and we cannot find a unique solution for x and y.
